channel.title: Gearty Grillings
channel.description: A weekly series of short video debates from LSE's Institute of Public Affairs. Conor Gearty, director of the IPA and professor of human rights law, subjects LSE academics to a five-minute grilling on their research and ideas.
channel.itunes:summary: A weekly series of short video debates from LSE's Institute of Public Affairs. Conor Gearty, director of the IPA and professor of human rights law, subjects LSE academics to a five-minute grilling on their research and ideas.
channel.copyright: Copyright © Terms of use apply see https://www.lse.ac.uk/termsOfUse/
channel.itunes:author: London School of Economics and Political Science

item.title: The final Gearty Grilling: Craig Calhoun on facing the future
item.itunes:author: Craig Calhoun
item.description: Contributor(s): Craig Calhoun | Craig Calhoun, Director of LSE and world-renowned social scientist, discusses his research and the future of LSE.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Craig Calhoun | Craig Calhoun, Director of LSE and world-renowned social scientist, discusses his research and the future of LSE.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Vanessa Iwowo on leadership
item.itunes:author: Vanessa Iwowo
item.description: Contributor(s): Vanessa Iwowo | Vanessa Iwowo, Fellow in the Department of Management, discusses her ideas on leadership in Africa.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Vanessa Iwowo | Vanessa Iwowo, Fellow in the Department of Management, discusses her ideas on leadership in Africa.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Matthew Connelly on hacking the archive and keeping government accountable
item.itunes:author: Matthew Connelly
item.description: Contributor(s): Matthew Connelly | Professor Matthew Connelly of LSE and Columbia University discusses official secrecy, data mining and why governments are not doing enough.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Matthew Connelly | Professor Matthew Connelly of LSE and Columbia University discusses official secrecy, data mining and why governments are not doing enough.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Judy Wajcman on the impact of digital technology
item.itunes:author: Judy Wajcman
item.description: Contributor(s): Judy Wajcman | Judy Wajcman, the Anthony Giddens Professor of Sociology, discusses the impact of digital technology on our lives.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Judy Wajcman | Judy Wajcman, the Anthony Giddens Professor of Sociology, discusses the impact of digital technology on our lives.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Pauline Barrieu on Statistics and modelling
item.itunes:author: Pauline Barrieu
item.description: Contributor(s): Pauline Barrieu | Pauline Barrieu, Professor in Statistics, discusses her approach to modelling and changing trends in the financial markets.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Pauline Barrieu | Pauline Barrieu, Professor in Statistics, discusses her approach to modelling and changing trends in the financial markets.

item.itunes:author: John Hills
item.description: Contributor(s): John Hills | John Hills, Professor of Social Policy, discusses inequality in the UK.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): John Hills | John Hills, Professor of Social Policy, discusses inequality in the UK.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Bridget Hutter on managing risk
item.itunes:author: Bridget Hutter
item.description: Contributor(s): Bridget Hutter | Bridget Hutter, Professor of Risk and Regulation, explains how risk can be managed but not eliminated.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Bridget Hutter | Bridget Hutter, Professor of Risk and Regulation, explains how risk can be managed but not eliminated.

item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Naila Kabeer | Naila Kabeer, Professor of Gender and Development at LSE's Gender Institute, discusses the changing role of women in capitalism.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Charlie Bean on how the Bank of England dealt with the economic crisis
item.itunes:author: Charlie Bean
item.description: Contributor(s): Charlie Bean | Charlie Bean, Professor of Economics and former Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy at the Bank of England, discusses how the Bank of England dealt with the economic crisis.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Charlie Bean | Charlie Bean, Professor of Economics and former Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy at the Bank of England, discusses how the Bank of England dealt with the economic crisis.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: The Noble Economist
item.itunes:author: Chris Pissarides
item.description: Contributor(s): Chris Pissarides | Chris Pissarides, Regius Professor of Economics and winner of a Nobel prize in 2010, discusses his ideas on how to run the economy.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Chris Pissarides | Chris Pissarides, Regius Professor of Economics and winner of a Nobel prize in 2010, discusses his ideas on how to run the economy.

item.description: Contributor(s): Connson Locke | Connson Locke, Assistant Professor of Management, discusses her research which shows that organisations benefit from a more diverse workforce.

item.itunes:author: Mukulika Banerjee
item.description: Contributor(s): Mukulika Banerjee | Mukulika Banerjee, Reader in Social Anthropology, discusses democracy in India and why the act of voting is so meaningful for the majority of the population.

item.description: Contributor(s): Richard Layard | Richard Layard, Emeritus Professor of Economics and Director of the Wellbeing Programme at LSE's Centre for Economic Performance, discusses what really makes us happy.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Richard Layard | Richard Layard, Emeritus Professor of Economics and Director of the Wellbeing Programme at LSE's Centre for Economic Performance, discusses what really makes us happy.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Sandra Jovchelovitch on how should we think about slums?
item.itunes:author: Sandra Jovchelovitch
item.description: Contributor(s): Sandra Jovchelovitch | Sandra Jovchelovitch, Professor of Social Psychology, discusses how methods of social change in Brazil's favelas could be used to change the lives of slum-dwellers around the world.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Sandra Jovchelovitch | Sandra Jovchelovitch, Professor of Social Psychology, discusses how methods of social change in Brazil's favelas could be used to change the lives of slum-dwellers around the world.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Nick Barr on Tuition Fees
item.itunes:author: Professor Nicholas Barr
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Nicholas Barr | Nicholas Barr, Professor of Public Economics and architect of the student loan, explains why students should regard it as a graduate tax, rather than a debt.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Nicholas Barr | Nicholas Barr, Professor of Public Economics and architect of the student loan, explains why students should regard it as a graduate tax, rather than a debt.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Danny Quah on Democracy in China
item.itunes:author: Professor Danny Quah
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Danny Quah | Must China emulate the political and social order of the West in order to compete, or is it possible to deliver comparable social and economic benefits by a different route? The IPA's Professor Conor Gearty grills Professor Danny Quah on the virtues and principles of Chinese democracy. Credits: Jon Adams (Filming and Editing), Tom Sturdy (Audio Recording), Jo Bale (Researcher and Producer).
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Danny Quah | Must China emulate the political and social order of the West in order to compete, or is it possible to deliver comparable social and economic benefits by a different route? The IPA's Professor Conor Gearty grills Professor Danny Quah on the virtues and principles of Chinese democracy. Credits: Jon Adams (Filming and Editing), Tom Sturdy (Audio Recording), Jo Bale (Researcher and Producer).

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Anne Power on growing inequality and why we need food banks
item.itunes:author: Professor Anne Power
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Anne Power | Anne Power, Professor of Social Policy, discusses growing inequality, why government should listen more to ordinary people and why we now need food banks.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Anne Power | Anne Power, Professor of Social Policy, discusses growing inequality, why government should listen more to ordinary people and why we now need food banks.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Alex Voorhoeve on why we need philosophers to help us question our intuitive moral judgements
item.itunes:author: Dr Alex Voorhoeve
item.description: Contributor(s): Dr Alex Voorhoeve | Alex Voorhoeve, Associate Professor in the Department of Philosophy, Logic and Scientific Method, discusses why we need philosophers to help us question our intuitive moral judgements.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Dr Alex Voorhoeve | Alex Voorhoeve, Associate Professor in the Department of Philosophy, Logic and Scientific Method, discusses why we need philosophers to help us question our intuitive moral judgements.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Heather Jones on World War I
item.itunes:author: Dr Heather Jones
item.description: Contributor(s): Dr Heather Jones | Dr Heather Jones, of the Department of International History, talks to Conor Gearty about why Britain willingly entered the First World War, and the socio-historical role the conflict plays in shaping national identity today. Socio-historical role the conflict plays in shaping national identity today.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Dr Heather Jones | Dr Heather Jones, of the Department of International History, talks to Conor Gearty about why Britain willingly entered the First World War, and the socio-historical role the conflict plays in shaping national identity today. item.title: Gearty Grilling: Christine Chinkin on violence against women and fact-finding in Gaza
item.itunes:author: Professor Christine Chinkin
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Christine Chinkin | Christine Chinkin, Professor of International Law, is grilled by Conor Gearty on a new European convention to combat violence against women, and her experiences on a UN fact-finding mission in Gaza. Credits: Jon Adams (Filming and Editing), Tom Sturdy (Audio Recording), Jo Bale (Researcher and Producer)
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Christine Chinkin | Christine Chinkin, Professor of International Law, is grilled by Conor Gearty on a new European convention to combat violence against women, and her experiences on a UN fact-finding mission in Gaza. item.title: Gearty Grilling: Gearty Grilling: Alan Sked on founding UKIP and his battle with Nigel Farage
item.itunes:author: Alan Sked
item.description: Contributor(s): Alan Sked | Alan Sked, Professor of International History and founder of UKIP, discusses the party’s liberal roots and his battle with Nigel Farage.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Alan Sked | Alan Sked, Professor of International History and founder of UKIP, discusses the party’s liberal roots and his battle with Nigel Farage.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Julian Le Grand on how choice and competition improves public services
item.itunes:author: Julian Le Grand
item.description: Contributor(s): Julian Le Grand | Julian Le Grand, Richard Titmuss professor of social policy and one of the principal architects of the UK Government’s public service reforms, explains why competition is the best way of enhancing hospitals and schools.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Julian Le Grand | Julian Le Grand, Richard Titmuss professor of social policy and one of the principal architects of the UK Government’s public service reforms, explains why competition is the best way of enhancing hospitals and schools.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Catherine Boone on land-related conflict in Africa
item.itunes:author: Professor Catherine Boone
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Catherine Boone | Catherine Boone, Professor of Comparative Politics and African Political Economy, discusses how land and property issues lie at the core of political conflict in Africa.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Catherine Boone | Catherine Boone, Professor of Comparative Politics and African Political Economy, discusses how land and property issues lie at the core of political conflict in Africa.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Tim Besley on the economic crisis
item.itunes:author: Professor Tim Besley
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Tim Besley | Conor Gearty grills Tim Besley, School Professor of Economics and Political Science at LSE and former member of the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Tim Besley | Conor Gearty grills Tim Besley, School Professor of Economics and Political Science at LSE and former member of the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee.

item.title: Gearty Grilling: Tony Travers On Decentralisation
item.itunes:author: Professor Tony Travers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers | In the first of a new series of weekly video debates from LSE's Institute of Public Affairs, Tony Travers, director of LSE London, argues that Britain would be better governed if more powers were moved to local government. Conor Gearty, director of the IPA and professor of human rights law, will be subjecting LSE academics to a five-minute grilling on their research and ideas in the new series, called The Gearty Grillings.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers | In the first of a new series of weekly video debates from LSE's Institute of Public Affairs, Tony Travers, director of LSE London, argues that Britain would be better governed if more powers were moved to local government. Conor Gearty, director of the IPA and professor of human rights law, will be subjecting LSE academics to a five-minute grilling on their research and ideas in the new series, called The Gearty Grillings.
